content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a risk-averse undergraduate student who values security, I would choose a strategy that aims to maximize my earnings while minimizing potential losses. In this game, both choices seem to offer comparable average payouts over the long run (R: 45$/round, B: 37.5$/round). However, choosing R exposes me to the risk of earning 0$ if my anonymous partner chooses B in a given round, while choosing B ensures I earn at least 35$. Given that this game has 75 rounds, it is reasonable to expect that my partner will choose both options approximately equally often. Therefore, to minimize the chances of zero earnings and maximize the potential for earning 40$, I would choose strategy B (in curly brackets: B}. This way, I have a higher probability of consistently earning more than 35$ per round while limiting the downside risk of earning nothing.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

As I value security and certainty, given my previous choice of B and my opponent's confirmation that they also chose B, I will continue to stick with my strategy of choosing B in this game. This way, I can maintain the higher probability of earning at least 35$ per round while limiting potential losses. I appreciate that the payoff is lower (40$) than if we both had chosen R (45$), but as a risk-averse undergraduate student, I prioritize security and consistency over occasional rewards with a greater variance in payouts. Therefore, for the next round, I will choose strategy B again (B).
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

As I am a risk-averse undergraduate student, my initial strategy was to minimize losses and maximize consistency. However, given that my choice of B resulted in an unexpected loss while my opponent chose R, which earned them 45$, I will modify my approach slightly for this round.

To avoid consistently losing money to the strategy where my partner chooses R while I choose B, I will switch my strategy temporarily to choosing R (R) for this round to try and even out the payouts over a shorter term. This change in strategy is based on the understanding that I cannot predict my opponent's choices consistently, but I can adjust my own strategy in response to their previous choice.

After making the switch to R, I will reassess my approach based on the outcome of this round and decide whether to continue with the temporary change or revert back to my original strategy of choosing B.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

As a risk-averse undergraduate student, my temporary switch to choosing R resulted in earning 0$ while my opponent earned 35$. This outcome reinforces that the strategy where I choose R and my opponent chooses B is not advantageous for me. In order to avoid further losses, I will revert back to my original strategy of choosing B (B) for the next round.

By consistently choosing B, I can minimize potential losses and aim to maximize earnings over the long run while maintaining security and certainty in my choices. This approach aligns with my risk-averse nature as an undergraduate student who values safety and predictability in all aspects of life.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
